title: WarnerMedia Boss Got $49 Million Stock Award
summary: The four-year grant made the entertainment leader AT&T's highest-paid executive in 2020. WarnerMedia boss Jason Kilar was the top-paid executive at AT&T Inc. last year after the telecom giant gave him a stock award worth $49 million to join the company on the cusp of its streaming video service's launch.

title: 'Cherry' Review: Twisted by Combat, Broken at Home
summary: Tom Holland stars as a troubled soldier returned from Iraq, based on the semiautobiographical novel by Nico Walker.. Here are a couple of things to know about "Cherry," now streaming on Apple TV+. No one in it is likable, let alone endearing or lovable. And nothing is understated, ever ever ever. Economists may disagree on the threat of inflation, but it's the curse of this madly overwrought film, which attempts to inflate a gritty novel about the horrors of war and opioid addiction into the epic journey of a troubled soul from alienation through nihilism to salvation. The running time is inflated too-142 minutes that feel even longer because of slo-mo sequences meant to confer a holiness on moments of mundane behavior, and a randomized approach to storytelling that assigns equal emotional weight to young lovers pledging their fidelity and armored vehicles stuck in the mud during an ambush in Iraq.

title: Lessons of the Long Covid Year
summary: Lockdowns made the pandemic suffering far worse than necessary.. When a SARS-like virus was reported spreading in Wuhan in late 2019, most Americans never imagined their own government would soon close schools, churches and businesses, order people to stay home, and spend more than $5 trillion to offset the damage. Yet a year later, here we are.

title: Here Come Climate Reparations
summary: Democrats create a fund to offset the damage from their policies.. Believe it or not, some Western Democrats are starting to push back against the Biden Administration's climate assault on their constituents.

title: Confiscation in Paradise
summary: Move to Hawaii, pay the nation's highest state income-tax rate.. With $350 billion in aid coming from Washington, what's on the agenda in Democratic statehouses? Hawaii's Legislature, the bluest in all 50 states, is bidding to pass the highest state tax rate in the land.

title: 'Come True' Review: Nightmares on Replay
summary: A high-school student suffering from terrifying dreams seeks help from a suspect sleep clinic in this sci-fi horror film from Anthony Scott Burns. Ordinary insomnia isn't a problem for the heroine of "Come True," which was written, directed, photographed and edited by Anthony Scott Burns. Sarah (Julia Sarah Stone) is so chronically zonked that she keeps nodding off in her high-school classes. What she suffers from is the scariness of her dream life, so what you think of her story will depend, at least in part, on your taste in movie dreams. If you lean toward the big-budget lucid dreaming of Christopher Nolan's "Inception," Sarah's nightmares can't hold a flickering candle. They're low-tech and low-res, in keeping with this low-budget excursion into sci-fi horror. And no one can accuse Mr. Burns's film of lucidity-the loose ends have loose ends-but it's ingenious and intriguing, right up to the silly finale, which should be forgiven if not ignored.

title: Unions and Democrats Attack the Right to Work
summary: The PRO Act, passed by the House, would force private workers to pay for labor representation.. Big Labor advanced halfway to achieving its top political priority Tuesday when the House narrowly passed the Protecting the Right to Organize Act. Despite the title, the PRO Act is stunningly, brazenly opposed to giving workers choices. It would strip from millions of workers the ability to make their own decisions about union participation.

title: Olympics Win the Hypocrisy Championship
summary: The IOC condemns a Japanese official for sexism but shrugs off Chinese genocide.. Former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori was fired by the Tokyo Olympics planning committee last month after making sexist remarks about women talking too much in meetings. At the height of the controversy, the International Olympic Committee issued a statement labeling his remarks "absolutely inappropriate" and highlighting the IOC's progress in promoting equality of the sexes, "a basic human right of profound importance and a Fundamental Principle of the Olympic Charter."

title: Cancer Is Different the Second Time
summary: We were surprised when my husband's disease recurred. But we felt better prepared, and it wasn't as shocking.. The first time my husband was diagnosed with cancer was 10 years ago, when a technician conducting an echocardiogram moved the wand lower than he usually would and found a grapefruit-size kidney tumor. We were shocked. In your 40s, life-threatening illness seems distant, the domain of the old. My husband underwent a partial nephrectomy, an unpleasant physical recovery and an emotional whirlwind, but we were done.

title: God, Puerto Rico and Bankruptcy Law
summary: I see restoring fiscal responsibility on the island as a deeply Christian activity.. On Monday Puerto Rico's oversight board filed a proposal for restructuring the island's $35 billion of debt and $50 billion of unfunded pension obligations. As chairman of the board, created by Congress in 2016 to help restore fiscal responsibility to the island, I've been immersed in the technical details from the beginning. This process wouldn't make many Christians think of Christianity, but it should.

title: Joe Manchin's Filibuster Test
summary: He says he won't change his mind on the filibuster, but what does he mean?. The future of the U.S. Senate-and all near-term domestic policy-is increasingly coming down to one simple question: Does West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin mean what he says?

summary: We eat like humans never have before. Is it right to call it addiction?. America's eating habits have changed radically over the past 40 years. We consume more and more food of less and less nutritional value. The nation's adult obesity rate is now 42.4%.

title: Texas Power Overcharges Get Pegged Lower
summary: State lawmakers learn that only a portion of overcharges from last month's blackouts are now considered recoverable for electricity users. Only a fraction of the $16 billion in Texas electricity overcharges stemming from last month's blackouts can likely be recovered for consumers by attempting to reverse the charges, an independent market monitor said Thursday.

title: Garland Prioritizes Jan. 6 Probe on First Day as Attorney General
summary: Former judge attends closed-door briefing on pro-Trump riot at Capitol after greeting Justice Department staff. title: Ulta Names President David Kimbell as Next CEO
summary: Current leader Mary Dillon will move into an executive chairwoman role starting in June. Ulta Beauty Inc. has named President David Kimbell as its next chief executive officer, succeeding current leader Mary Dillon, as the company continues to weather challenges from slower store foot traffic brought on by the pandemic.

title: The Hirshhorn Sculpture Garden Redesign: Paving Paradise
summary: Washington's modern art museum wants to turn much of its welcoming, verdant garden, so perfect for displaying its outdoor sculpture, into an impersonal hardscape to be used mainly for performance art.. The Hirshhorn Museum's Sculpture Garden in Washington is nearly perfect; of course, it must be destroyed. This is the paradox of landscape architecture: The more sensitive and subtle the garden, the more invisible it is-even to its custodians. At a certain point they can mistake it for an opportunity to exploit rather than a sacred trust to protect.

title: California Says Car Insurers Overcharged During the Pandemic
summary: State gives auto-insurance companies until April 30 to detail plans for returning premiums to California policyholders. California regulators are ordering car insurers to refund significantly more money to the state's vehicle owners, accusing them of overcharging customers as wrecks last year plummeted due to reduced driving during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 'Bloodlands' Review: Tale of Newly Troubled Times
summary: New evidence causes a Belfast detective to reopen the case of a serial assassin dating from before Northern Ireland's Good Friday Agreement, one of whose victims was his wife. The four-part "Bloodlands," a hit British thriller now streaming on Acorn TV, isn't just about murder, betrayal and Irish gun-barrel politics. It's about the power of storytelling. Northern Ireland, as portrayed in the series at least, is so unstable that few characters want to even mention its bloody past, and that's something reflected in the production itself: There's a straining for silence, as if the series might become complicit in disturbing the peace. But can a people be free if their defining conflict goes unspoken? The result is an agitated tension percolating beneath the surface skullduggery and violence.

title: 'Own the Room' Review: Pitching the Future
summary: Young entrepreneurs vie for the top spot in a global competition that recognizes world-changing ideas. Competition documentaries-about spelling bees, Scrabble, crossword puzzles, cooking-are something of a cliché, and for good reason: A contest provides a narrative. And drama. And, depending on the personalities involved, it usually gives you someone to root for. Customarily, a large group of contestants is followed along the path to the podium; the editing room makes it appear that the director knew who the winner would be all along. Sometimes there are parents screaming maniacally from the figurative sidelines. There's always an underdog.

title: Tech Shares Push S&P 500 to Record
summary: Nasdaq jumps 2.5%, while S&P joins Dow at new highs. A rebound in shares of technology companies propelled the S&P 500 to a record close Thursday, as investors snatched up shares of growth companies that have lagged behind in recent weeks as bond yields soared.

title: Tempted to Travel to the Caribbean? Know the Covid Rules
summary: Most of the region's islands are open to U.S. visitors now, but you'll have to navigate a multitude of pandemic obstacles before you can flop down on the beach. Here's the advice you need.. IN MID-FEBRUARY, when a cold snap set in across much of America, Tami Irons, a system administrator at a hospital network in Painesville, Ohio, chased the sun to St. John, the smallest and lushest of the U.S. Virgin Islands. She and her husband have been vacationing on St. John annually since 2005, and not even the continuing pandemic was going to stop them. "Getting out of the snow and the cold always makes us breathe a little better," said Ms. Irons.

title: Equality Goes With Freedom, Equity Doesn't
summary: The government can't measure equality of opportunity, but it can measure equality of result.. Charles Lipson is right ("'Equity' Is a Mandate to Discriminate," op-ed, March 5), and the drumbeat is getting louder that result, not opportunity, is what demonstrates the existence of discrimination. My father, who was chairman of General Motors in the late 1970s, used to say: "The government can't measure equality of opportunity, but it can measure equality of result. If the results are not equal, they assume unequal opportunity." Ingenuity, inventiveness, entrepreneurial skill, determination and, most important, effort are extremely difficult to measure, but those are usually the key factors in creating the result. Until the government figures out how to measure those factors, "equity" will never be properly measured.

title: Science and Creationism in Serious Colleges
summary: Dr. Swamidass's unilateral demands for a "principled compromise" and "higher standards" for Christian colleges and accrediting associations do not center on science, as he misleadingly claims, but rather on scientific models and the evidence for them.. S. Joshua Swamidass ("A Compromise on Creationism," Houses of Worship, March 5) can offer no evidence in asserting that Bob Jones University grants degrees requiring course credits in "creation science," because there is in reality no such thing. We simply teach science.

title: The Best Corkscrews According to Wine Pros
summary: Our wine columnist talked to sommeliers, winemakers and even a world-class corkscrew collector. These are the tools they recommend for elegant and efficient uncorking.. BACK WHEN we were having dinners at other people's homes, any time I saw my host struggling with a less-than-desirable corkscrew, I felt duty-bound to provide an alternative. Take, for example, my friends Tom and Sue: When I first met them, they were opening wine bottles with one of those two-lever, butterfly-type corkscrews that rip up corks as often as they remove them. The next time we met, I brought them a much better tool, the Richartz waiter's corkscrew. A decade or so later, Tom and Sue still use it.

title: How to Decorate With Secondhand Furniture From Craigslist and Nextdoor
summary: Clothing designer Raquel Allegra decorated a 24-room house in Taos, N.M., almost entirely from vintage finds without making it look like a thrift shop. Here, her tricks.. A LITTLE OVER a year ago, when Raquel Allegra decided to buy an 8,000-square-foot second home in Taos, N.M., the fashion designer was set on decorating it almost exclusively with previously owned pieces. "There's just so much available in the world," she said, "and they've had a life before they came to me, which is important to me." So began a wide-ranging hunt: on Craigslist, on the Nextdoor app and at shops near her home in the Topanga neighborhood of Los Angeles. "I got my friends in a van and filled it up and sent it all out to Taos."

Addressing Syria's dictator, the former ophthalmologist Bashar al-Assad, they wrote, "Your turn has come, doctor!" The boys were arrested and tortured, sparking protests across the country, especially in its capital, Damascus.

Chinese President Xi Jinping's recent crackdown on the empire of China's best-known entrepreneur has put an end to that.

title: Trump Call to Georgia Lead Investigator Reveals New Details
summary: Then-president says that 'something bad happened' and presses for investigation into Fulton County votes. ATLANTA-Then-President Donald Trump urged the chief investigator of the Georgia Secretary of State's office to look for fraud during an audit of mail-in ballots in a suburban Atlanta county, on a phone call he made to her in late December.

title: Immigrant Bought a Domed Stadium for $583,000
summary: Andreas Apostolopoulos, who has died at age 68, made his name betting on depressed Detroit-area real estate. Andreas Apostolopoulos was an obscure Toronto-based investor in industrial real estate until 2009. Then he bought a domed stadium that no one else seemed to want.

title: Number Puzzles (Saturday, March 13)
The NFL Coach, the Nobel Prize Winner and One Crazy Idea to Fix Overtime
summary: The Baltimore Ravens proposed a new rule that would radically overhaul the structure of overtime games to make them more fun-and more fair. The Baltimore Ravens recently proposed a bold change to the rule that governs how overtime games in the NFL work. It's unorthodox. It's a little bit crazy. And it has the endorsement of a Nobel Prize-winning economist who says it will make football more fun-and more fair.

title: Behind on Rent? You May Qualify for Federal Assistance
summary: Latest coronavirus relief bill includes help for tenants who are behind on rent and utilities. WASHINGTON-The coronavirus relief bill passed by the House on Wednesday includes help for tenants who are behind on their rent and utility bills.

title: Pasta Milanese
summary: Like all the dishes Sicilians serve to celebrate St. Joseph's Day, pasta Milanese is rich in symbolism as well as flavor. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: This Pasta Is a Party Waiting to Happen
summary: Like all the dishes Sicilians serve to celebrate St. Joseph's Day, pasta Milanese is rich in symbolism as well as flavor. AS AN Irish/Italian American growing up in northern New Jersey, I viewed March as a month of dueling saints: Patrick and Joseph. A Sunday-sauce type of family, we endured corned beef and cabbage only once a year; the foods of Sicily were much more prominent on our table.

title: GameStop, AMC, Bumble: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: The number of Americans applying for jobless benefits declined. Here's what we're watching ahead of Thursday's opening bell.

title: Coronavirus Outbreak at Gyms Roils Hong Kong's Finance Industry
summary: Banks, brokerages and asset managers have vacated offices after Covid-19 rippled through Hong Kong's expatriate community. Hong Kong's finance sector was roiled Thursday by a coronavirus outbreak that emanated from fitness centers in the city, with large banks, brokerages and asset managers vacating some offices and employees rushing to get tested for Covid-19.

title: 13 Ways to Jazz Up a Suit
summary: New spring suiting ideas take note from a musical golden age. This season, the snappiest suits capture all the energy and flair of a swinging jazz club. The tailored daily uniform may have fallen by the wayside in favor of loungewear during the work-from-home era, but for many men, there's nothing more uplifting. This season sees a range of colorful options that can be thrown on for an easy and immediate upgrade, including a pale pink Tod's option, Gucci prints, brown Ralph Lauren pinstripes and crisp whites from Louis Vuitton .

title: Entrepreneur Chris Whittle Looks to Bolster For-Profit School Network
summary: The New York executive plans a merger, as his company faces lawsuits alleging unpaid contracts. With his company facing lawsuits alleging millions of dollars in unpaid contracts, New York entrepreneur Chris Whittle says he has a new approach for his goal of building a global network of for-profit schools.

title: Military Spending, Deficit Disputes Could Trip Up Democrats' Ambitions
summary: Intraparty differences could complicate effort to advance package focused on infrastructure and healthcare. WASHINGTON-Democrats' first big legislative push on the coronavirus relief package wasn't easy. Their plans for another big package potentially focused on infrastructure and healthcare is expected to be harder at every turn, beginning with the initial step of approving a budget.

title: The One Phone Call That Changed Marcus Rashford's Life
summary: The Premier League footballer and activist on an unexpected phone call that he'll never forget, the athlete he'd most like to meet and the person he talks to before every game. What's the one thing this year has taught you?

title: Shell Appoints New Chairman to Navigate Energy Transition
summary: Former BHP CEO Andrew Mackenzie to help guide company's plans to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and expand in low-carbon energy. LONDON- Royal Dutch Shell PLC has appointed Andrew Mackenzie as its new chairman, tapping a mining veteran to oversee the oil and gas giant as it navigates the transition to low-carbon energy.

title: EU Extends Vaccine Export Ban Option While Touting Exports
summary: Move follows EU efforts to hit back at critics of its slow-rolling vaccine campaign. BRUSSELS-The European Union is extending a mechanism that allows member states to block vaccine exports, keeping the system in place until the end of June.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Eligibility Varies From State to State
summary: Discrepancies by location are prompting some people to travel for shots. States are making new groups eligible for Covid-19 vaccines at a faster but uneven pace, creating discrepancies that are stoking confusion and encouraging some people to trek to places with more lenient policies.

title: Major League Baseball Eyes a Return to Full Ballparks
summary: The Texas Rangers said they would allow 100% capacity at their home opener on April 5. Most clubs will start at reduced capacity and ramp up as they can.. Sports as a live entertainment product has largely been dormant in the U.S. for a year, wiped away by the coronavirus pandemic. As spring arrives-and Covid-19 cases drop, hospitalizations plummet and vaccines roll out-Major League Baseball is making a bold move toward bringing fans back in large numbers.

title: Atlanta's Crime Wave Makes Some Residents Look to the Suburbs
summary: Buckhead group explores seceding from the city amid rise in violent crime; 'Everybody is on edge'. ATLANTA-Lauren LeNoir had always felt safe on her quiet street in Buckhead, the city's wealthiest neighborhood, known for its upscale malls and mansions. But that all changed when she was coming home from work one night in January.

title: Prince William Says Royals 'Not Racist'
summary: Second in line to British throne says he hasn't spoken to his brother since Oprah Winfrey interview. LONDON-Prince William on Thursday said his family isn't racist, the first public rebuttal from a senior member of the British monarchy of allegations made by Prince Harry and Meghan Markle about racism in the royal ranks.

title: The Treasury Market Could Soon Get More Love
summary: While markets are jittery about U.S. government bonds, foreign investors now have a big incentive to buy them with currency hedges. Like beauty, the value of a financial asset is in the eye of the beholder. Right now, Treasurys look much better from outside of the U.S.

title: Homebuyers Are Heading to Florida During Covid, but Nearly as Many Are Moving Out
summary: Thanks to hurricanes, heat and red-hot home prices, the state's population growth hit its lowest rate since 2014 during the pandemic. David Gewirtz never got used to the heat, even after 15 years in Florida.

title: A Quick Vacation Home
summary: The Cunninghams swiftly sold their West Palm Beach property after home prices rapidly rose in the area.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Lineage Logistics Raises $1.9 Billion to Expand Cold-Storage Reach
summary: The world's largest refrigerated-storage operator is eyeing more acquisitions, new facilities as its valuation reaches about $18 billion. The market for cold storage is heating up as the largest players in temperature-controlled warehousing move deeper into global food supply chains.

title: New Analysis Seeks to Guide Educators on Reopening Schools
summary: A review of 130 studies on school reopenings world-wide says officials must weigh long-term impacts of school closures on children. A year after a new coronavirus prompted an abrupt wave of school closures, the science is becoming clearer about how schools can reopen safely and what role they play in further spread.

title: Champions League Moves On Without Messi and Ronaldo
summary: An era appears to close as Juventus and Barcelona crash out of Europe. PARIS-Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo spent the past 15 years redefining what was possible in the Champions League. They were the immovable fixtures of the European soccer spring. Reaching the semifinals was practically a guarantee for them. And more often than not, one or the other would go on to win the whole thing-a feat Messi and Ronaldo pulled off a combined nine times since 2006.

title: Fukushima Nuclear Cleanup Is Just Beginning
summary: Resume Subscription. A resolution to the crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant remains a distant goal a decade after three of its reactors melted down.

title: Companies Are Holding Off on Firing Workers Right Now
summary: Most Popular News. Millions of workers have been laid off during the pandemic, but cutting ties with individual employees over performance issues has become vastly more complicated, several employers say.

title: Brink's Got Outsiders to Count Newly-Acquired Gold, Silver Bars
summary: Just over a year ago, Brink's bought most of the cash operations business of G4S. But coronavirus restrictions prevented it from taking stock of inventories on its own. Counting the assets that The Brink's Co. acquired as part of an $860 million deal took the company's finance chief nearly a year because of pandemic-related restrictions.

title: Cash-Out Refinancings Hit Highest Level Since Financial Crisis
summary: Home prices have soared during the coronavirus pandemic, prompting more borrowers to pocket cash from refis. Americans extracted more cash from their homes through cash-out refinancings in 2020 than in any year since the financial crisis.

title: Biotech Companies Seek to Restore Functions to Spinal-Cord Injury Patients
summary: Stem cells, gene therapy among treatments under study for paralyzing injuries. Biotechnology companies and researchers are studying treatments that could help patients with spinal-cord injuries recover abilities to move and function that they have lost.

title: Small Businesses Seek More Time to Apply for PPP Loans
summary: Lenders and advocates for firms say program changes, approval delays are creating a time crunch before March 31 deadline. Small-business advocates are calling on the federal government to extend the March 31 deadline to apply for a loan from the Paycheck Protection Program, citing recent changes made to the program and delays in processing applications.

title: The Real Rally to Watch Isn't in Stocks
summary: The global real-estate market is booming in a way that was confined to a handful of countries after the financial crisis. Stock markets are exciting, perhaps particularly to financial journalists. But the bigger impact, and the bigger risks, are in a larger and slower-moving market: real estate.

title: Toyota Chief Cautions Apple Over Car Plans
summary: Akio Toyoda says new entrants to the sector should be ready for 40-year commitment. TOKYO- Toyota Motor Corp. President Akio Toyoda said he welcomed the possible entry of Apple Inc. into the car business but said the iPhone maker should be ready for a decadeslong commitment to its customers.

title: House Passes Gun-Control Measures Backed by Democrats
summary: The bills would expand background checks to nearly all gun sales and extend the window for background checks to 10 days. WASHINGTON-The House passed a pair of gun-control bills that were blocked in the last Congress, a priority for Democratic leaders frustrated by years of little success on the issue amid broad Republican opposition.

title: Covid-19 Antibody Drug Effective in Study, GlaxoSmithKline and Vir Say
summary: The makers plan to seek authorization of the drug, given its 85% effectiveness preventing hospitalizations and deaths. A monoclonal-antibody drug reduced hospitalizations or death from Covid-19 by 85% compared with a placebo in a clinical trial, said Vir Biotechnology Inc. and GlaxoSmithKline PLC, the drug's developers.

title: Los Angeles Schools to Reopen for Youngest Students in April
summary: Elementary students will return to classrooms part-time, while middle- and high-school students continue online learning. The Los Angeles Unified School District reached a tentative agreement with its teachers union that would allow some students in the nation's second-largest school district to resume in-person learning for the first time in more than a year.

title: ESPN Strikes Seven-Year Deal for Rights to NHL Games
summary: Deal turns ESPN+ into streaming home of out-of-market local-TV hockey games. Walt Disney Co. 's ESPN and the National Hockey League said they struck a seven-year deal that will bring the Stanley Cup Finals to Disney's ABC broadcast network and make hundreds of local-TV games available on the ESPN+ streaming service.

title: Justice Department Backs College Athletes in Supreme Court Case
summary: Biden administration files brief against NCAA's rules limiting student-athlete compensation as justices prepare to hear case this month. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court to side with college athletes who are challenging the NCAA's limits on their compensation, adding the government's voice to a high-stakes case scheduled for arguments later this month.

title: AMC Reopening More Theaters Closed by Covid-19
summary: Sales fell 89% in the fourth quarter, but CEO expects new movies, vaccine distribution to drive better results this year. AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. has reopened many of its theaters in recent weeks after a winter surge of coronavirus cases prompted the company to re-close several cinemas at the end of 2020 when sales fell 89%.

title: Colombia in Uproar After Military Bombing of Drug Gang Kills at Least One Girl
summary: Defense Minister refers to youth in jungle camps as 'war machines;' 12 people died in March 2 aerial strike. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-The death of at least one teenage girl in an aerial bombardment of a jungle camp operated by a narco-trafficking group has touched off outrage aimed at Colombia's Defense Ministry, which has been under pressure to bring a range of armed groups to heel.

title: Brazil Overtakes U.S. in Daily Covid-19 Deaths
summary: P.1 strain from the Amazon fills up ICUs across South America's most populous country; some patients left to die. SÃO PAULO-Brazil has overtaken the U.S. as the country with the most daily Covid-19 cases and deaths in the world, as an aggressive strain of the disease from the Amazon leaves Latin America's biggest nation scrambling for space in hospitals and cemeteries.

title: Roblox Shares Jump in Public-Markets Debut
summary: Market capitalization of the videogame platform now stands at roughly $45 billion. Shares of videogame platform Roblox Corp. soared in their public debut Wednesday, in an indication that the mania that gripped the IPO market late last year shows no sign of abating.
